segments.text: B for Boy, R as in Robert, OT, MAN, Rotman.
And I'm a former newspaper man who went into the public relations field and ultimately built a large public relations counseling firm headquartered in Chicago.
And we ended up with five offices in five cities and abroad in London.
I was CEO and chairman of that company.
up until about five years ago when I merged it with a New York firm.
Our firm was called Hershey, Rotman & Druck, and then I merged it with another firm, and I became president of that firm.
Then I decided to retire three years ago.
I now have a company called Morris B. Rotman Associates, although I still serve as a consultant to that combined firm.
For all intents and purposes, I'm no longer involved with my previous firm.
I'm retired from there.
And I do my own thing.
And included in my own thing is relationships with about six companies that know me very well, know me for a long time, where I give them some of my time.
And most of the time, however, I do my own thing, whatever that may be.
Where was your residence for the most part?
My residence is still in Chicago.
In Chicago, OK.
where my wife and I spent six months, and where the headquarters of our company was.

I also have a residence in Palm Springs, California, where I spend six months of the year, from approximately November to May, and from which, it's really not Palm Springs, it's Rancho Mirage, but I refer to Palm Springs as that's the one most people understand.
They say Rancho Mirage, they wonder which state it's in.
Best known for Gerald Ford,
And Frank Sinatra and people like that, not me.
But I commute from Palm Springs to my various client relationships.
During those months, I'm there.
And I move all my equipment, my files, and all that stuff.
So in effect, I set up an office for six months.
And now we're going to make the return to Chicago in May.
This is pretty much a regular routine?
Yeah.
How much time do you spend here in this area?
Houston area?
Well, I come down every couple months for three days.
Most of the time it's on a three-month interval, about four times a year.
But I also come down for very special events, mostly involved with my personal relationship with the Mitchell family.
Sometimes I come down for celebrations, family things, opening of the pavilion.
So I would say I get to Houston or Galveston.
maybe six times a year.
And as a result of our professional relationship, George and I have become close friends, and our families are close to one another.
So that we consider both of us, both our families, extended families in a way.
And we've gotten to know all the kids.
They know our kids.
And it's been a wonderful relationship of a true friend.
Where did you do your journalism work?
I assume your background is in journalism?
Well, the kind of background I have, I wouldn't recommend to my son, nor to anybody else's son.
If you wanted to break into journalism or public relations, don't do it the way I did it, because it would be almost impossible today.
I've only had a year and a half of college work.
I was in junior college in Chicago.
And there was economic uncertainty in my family, and I was the only one to help resolve that.
So I went to work, even though I had other brothers.
I had an opportunity when I was in college.
I was editor of the paper, and a weekly newspaper chain gave me a chance to work for two weeks.
And they were impressed with what I did, and the publisher finally said, hey, you can finish your college work at night.
We're going to start a new newspaper, and we'll make you the editor.
That's great.
I was all of them.
I think I must have been eighteen or nineteen at that time.
That's great.
That's exciting.
And I became editor of a paper called the Lakeview Booster in Chicago, a neighborhood newspaper.
And I've never stopped working since.
I went from there to being- are you interested in my- Yes, sir.
Yeah, we really are.
I worked for the newspaper for about a year, and then they started a newspaper out in a place called Cistro, Illinois.
home base of the gangsters at one time, Al Capone's headquarters.
And the same group of people who owned the paper I worked for started a newspaper in Cicero, Berwyn, and Oak Park, the three suburbs there.
And they really needed an editor and a circulation manager, jack of all trades.
And I went out there to do that kind of work.
And I worked there for about a year.
It was a very unusual experience because I wore at least ten hats.
Yeah, you got to pick up the business side of it very quickly, too, I'm sure.
Well, I sold ads.
I was circulation manager.
I was editor.
I was reporter.
I was proofreader.
I ran a travel bureau when I had a free day on Wednesday.
I'd be waiting on the bus.
You know, you make money wherever you can, so I used to sell tickets.
And then Wednesday nights I ran a tour of Chinatown.
Is that right?
For the club ladies.
All for, I think, I was making $28 a week.
And then from then, they started a newspaper on the west side of Chicago.
And I went there as editor and publisher, in a way.
I did everything again.
And then I went to the City News Bureau of Chicago, which is a famed training ground for journalists.
And I became, I think, the first man or woman, first employee they ever hired who wasn't on the dean's list of a journalism school.
But the managing editor there took a chance on me based on my
background and I rose very rapidly there from reporter to rewrite man to editor.
And from there I went to the Community Fund of Chicago, which is a fundraising red feather agency.
They're raising funds for all the health and welfare agencies in Chicago.
I became public relations director there for two years and I met a lot of important executives in the business community, met most of the top newspaper men because I was representing
You know, a cohesive community interest there.
And a man who had a little public relations for him by the name of Bill Hershey was impressed with my work.
We had something to do with one another.
He came in, asked my help, and my boss gave me.
And he went to my boss and said, I'd like to hire that young man.
And I was very upset.
I didn't want to leave, because I had a pretty good job there.
But he kept after me.
And I finally said, listen, I'll come in as you make me a partner.
So I came in as a partner of his firm in 1949, and we worked together.
Well, it was 1946, and we worked together for a couple of years, and then he died.
He had a stroke, and luckily we were by then a corporation, and I had the right to buy his stock.
The firm was $74,000 a year in gross.
That's the kind of fees we had.
Making no money at all.
And I built it.
into a six million dollar firm.
You know, just maybe desperation, whatever it was, maybe I was there at the right time.
Until we, we were the largest public relations firm in Chicago.
What kind of accounts did you, were you developing in those days?
Well in the early days, I guess the first tent strike I had was I got a small division of General Motors called the Hertz Rent-A-Car.
Hertz was an obscure little company.
Most people don't know it was owned by General Motors.
And GM tried to hide it under a bushel basket, so to speak, because they felt there was a conflict between renting and selling cars.
And they were concerned too many people knew about it.
And so Hertz merchandised on its own without too much support from General Motors.
And ultimately, General Motors sold it off.
They wanted to get rid of an embarrassment.
I think it was a mistake in a way, maybe.
When I was working for Hertz, it was a $20 million company, something like that.
And now it must be close to a billion, a large company.
But that was a very important breakthrough for me, because I sold a national account.

And I would say that it had another element that I liked, in that Hertz was so small that there was a merchandising committee, a marketing committee, so to speak, made up of the principal licensees around the country.
And they ran the company.
And I was on that committee.
See, Hertz was a kind of an association in a way.
The central organization, Hertz Incorporated, owned what they call stations of their own.
And there were a handful of them, leading cities.
But the best cities were in Miami and Denver and I think Los Angeles.
And those weren't owned by Hertz.
And when Hertz ultimately went public,
They would then start one by one to buy out most of the independent licensees.
In those days, it was these buccaneers, these entrepreneurs that were running the company.
And I sat in with them.
And they respected my opinion, even though I was quite a young man.
And that really helped me develop as an individual, as a professional.
And I really enjoyed that.
Then, little by little, I began to sell accounts.
We had an office in Rochester, New York.
When my partner was alive, we had a couple of accounts there.
And I built that office, though, where we had about 14 people working for us there.
We had all the leading business in Rochester.
We had the Bausch & Lomb, Graflex Company, the makers of the camera.
That's headquarters of Kodak as well.
Pardon?
That used to be the headquarters of Kodak as well.
It is still the headquarters of Kodak, sure.
But we had a handful.
Taylor Instruments had some wonderful accounts there.
And then we...

We had an affiliation in New York, but when I sold an account in New York City and opened my own office ultimately, from a half-time employee working for us, you know, to the point where I guess when I hung up my shingle, we had about 150 employees there, you know.
An aside, I was thinking about the other day when I was talking to the staff here, Taylor Instruments.
I was called over.
by the PR director.
He wanted to get us in there.
Been trying for a year.
He knew I was in town.
He said, listen, he's having a meeting today, and they agreed to see you.
I said, I'm not even prepared.
I don't have anything.
I don't have an easel or anything like that.
He said, come over, do the best you can.
So I came.
All I had was a handful of flippings, you know, illustrating what we did for Bausch and Lund.
And I got into this room, and it was kind of fall, and the red ear was on.
And it was so hot.
And of course, I was nervous.
I was perspiring for juice.
And I started to say to the chairman of the company, he said, what kind of organization are you?
I said, well, we're kind of a shirt sleeves organization, you know.
Get down the brass tacks and all that stuff.
Principled and honest and all that.
And I was perspiring.
And I said, do you mind if I take off my coat?
So I took off my jacket and I hung it up on something.
Everybody else was suited up.
And they told me the turning point
was I dramatically illustrated how sure you were.
And I did it unconsciously.
I didn't do it for that reason.
And the other account, of course, Bausch & Lomb was a tremendous coup because we were selected from competition.
All other major agencies wanted that account.
I think the reason we got it was we had another account in Rochester.
We had a little office there, finally.
Bausch & Lomb became very important to me in my whole professional career because at one time they developed the cinemascope lens with Spiros Skouras and 20th Century Fox.
And they did the first film, cinemascope film, The Rope, if you remember that.
Yeah, sure.
And President Bausch & Lomb called me in one day and said, you know, we deserve a special award from the Academy for our development in that scientific field.
optics system, and he said, all of our people have tried to talk to the academy.
In fact, the head of the academy's technical advisory committee has tried to get it for us, and maybe you can do something.
Do you know anybody out there?
I said, no, but I'll sure as hell try.
So I contacted a number of people, and I found out who the head of the academy was.
It was a woman named Margaret Herrick.
Do you want to know all this?
Yeah, go ahead.
This is fun.
This is fascinating.
And Margaret Herrick...
I got an appointment with her through a contact, and she said, when she talked to me, she said, I'm only going to give you a half hour.
So she knew what I wanted.
So I sat down and I said, how do you go about getting an award?
I think they deserve it.
She said, you don't ask for it.
They've made the mistake of asking for an award through the years.
So I did something that was unconsciously brilliant.
I said to her, do you mind if I destroy the file?
That wasn't, again, it isn't a device that I invented.
It was just an idea.
Why not start fresh?
It's a conscious reaction.
She had a kind of a wry look to her face.
She was kind of bemused.
She reached in her phone.
She gave it to me.
I tore it up and I threw it in her wastebasket.
I said, okay, let's start fresh.
The half hour extended to about three and a half hours.
She's a very busy lady.
She told me how people have
gotten awards for contributions to the motion picture industry.
Honest contributions.
And I said to her, is there anything that's needed in the motion picture industry I might be able to influence my client to do on a long-range basis?
And they were looking for a means of copying all those films that were copied on paper and were turning into dust in the Library of Congress.
You look at history and motion picture, a lot of that stuff's on paper.
And it's disappearing.
You know, a national treasure.
And Bausch & Lomb had copying equipment of all kinds.
And I convinced Bausch & Lomb to contribute all that copying equipment.
And then the whole process started, which still goes on to this day.
Now, they didn't get an award for that.
No.
But the climate was right, so that the Academy felt...
Appreciated what they were doing.
Knew them.
All of a sudden, they looked at Bausch & Lomb in a different light.
And about a year later,
The head of the academy called me and says, can you get your client to Hollywood on such and such a date?
I know it was the day of the Oscar.
I said, what's the purpose?
Just get them there.

Now, what happened there, the reason it was a turning point in my life, was that lady, a very smart lady, was looking at me, as well as my client, and she was saying to herself, this guy may be the guy who can handle our public relations, which is
on a thought that never occurred to me.
You know, it was a dream.
Small agency in Chicago to get the famous Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
Yeah, so she said to me in her first, what would you think about handling an account like this?
I said, well, I think it would be fantastic.
I said, but I don't know, number one, I don't know too much about the agency.
Number two, I guess I'd have to open an office here, and I don't know if I could afford to.
And number three,
I understand you have an incumbent, and I never take business away from anybody unless they've been informed that they're going out.
I said, have you informed the incumbent?
She said, no.
I said, when you do, if you want me to, I'll come back.
Well, that impressed her.
It's, again, one of these unconscious things you do.
Now, maybe it's part of your basic morality that you do the right thing under certain circumstances.
And my morality has never been to take an account away from anybody, an incumbent.
I've done it.
client asked me to come in, I always see that the circumstances are such that they're totally dissatisfied and have informed the other agency that they're going to interview us.
Because I don't want people to do that to me either.
No, you're right.
So about three months later, six months later, whatever the case may be, she called me.
Would you come back and talk?
Have you informed?
Yes.
Okay, I came back and I made a presentation.
And she told her directors that we were going to get the accounts.
Well, all hell broke out in Hollywood, because there must be 50 firms that wanted it, and they were all insiders, and I was an outsider.
My advantage was that there would be no conflicts.
And if I had the Academy account, I wouldn't handle motion.
PictureStars or studios didn't want them.
And I told them, when I made my presentation, I wouldn't take any conflicts.
Again, it was an unconscious, or maybe it was deliberate, move on my part that was right.
And there was such a hullabaloo.
I saw telegrams from Samuel Goldwyn, all kinds of people.
How can you select an outsider?
Here's a firm you want to select.
But they called us back, and they interviewed 20 agencies.
And when I went in there, I decided I wasn't going to make a presentation.
I was going to talk about integrity.
And I closed my presentation, which I did.
And I talked about our agencies and my principles and what I believed in and all that.
And we got the accounts.
And it's lasted to this day.
Is that right?
My agency still has it, sure.
Is that right?
And about three years ago, I was elected an associate member of the Academy, which is a rare honor for a layman.
I'm not in the motion picture business.
And I still go to the Academy Awards.
I've gone to 35.
That's exciting.
That's quite a career.
So I'm most prominently identified, because that's such a celebrity account, I'm most prominently identified with the Academy.
in public relations circles.
You ask people about me, they say, oh yeah, he worked with the Academy so many years.
But actually our agency was a corporate public relations firm with only one show business account.
Yeah, that was the Academy.
We did handle the Tournament of Roses for a number of years.
That was the only other one.
But that's kind of show business.
But all our other accounts, as it developed, were major corporations.
And we grew from our Chicago office.
We already had a Rochester office, but we opened in New York.
And then when I got the Academy, I opened in Los Angeles with, again, a one-man office.
And then I got the Mattel account out there.
Barbie doll and all that.
That became a very large account.
Then we got the Avocado Board out there.
Who was the Avocado Board then?
Avocados.
Oh, yeah, sure, food production.
Yeah, yeah.
And marketing advisory boards.
And they have budgets and they hire PR firms.
So we did a program to get more people to use avocados in a variety of ways.
And we had the Kiwi account and the California pistachios and, you know, all those things need public relations activity.

It occurred to me that our firm had service capabilities in Europe, and I bought into a British firm, and they added our name to theirs, and then we developed a network of firms throughout the world, so that we had an associated firm, where we referred business to one another, and in some cases they used our name on the door, and it was closer than just a loose affiliation, and we had a
a relationship in Tokyo, and in Milan, and Rome, and Paris, and Scandinavian countries, and South America.
You know, where our clients might need services.
You did a history of your firm done.
That sounds like a good project.
Well, yeah.
I started to write, make some notes on, not so much history of the firm.
You know, that's, I don't know how interesting that is.
What's interesting
I would say is some of the campaigns that I've been in, and some of the extraordinary people that I've worked with, like George, a fellow who invented the idea of the rent-a-car business.
Or I worked for Harold Janine at ITT.
Those are some of the great men of American industry.
And I worked with some prominent politicians, like Stevenson.
Yeah, those are...
Now, how did I get involved with George?
Is that what you want to know?
Yes, sir.
I became a member in 1950, I became a member of a group called Young Presidents Organization.
Are you familiar with YPO?
We know, we've heard of it.
If you would elaborate a bit, that would be very useful.
Well, there was a fellow by the name of Ray Hickok, Hickok Belt, who became president
father's company, tender age, maybe he was in his 20s, and he realized he needed to talk to peers.
You know, you could talk to an attorney, talk to an accountant, but nobody was a contemporary.
So they start talking to a couple of fellows he knew who had the same predicament he had.
And before you knew it, there were five guys who were meeting together on a regular basis.
Well, today there are probably 6,000 members of the Young Presidents Organization.
And the criteria for admission to YPO was that you
In those days, you had to have 50 employees, a million dollars in gross value, not net worth, but gross value.
And you had to be under 40 years of age when you became president of your company.
And you retired.
You retired into Never Never Land when you were 49.
You became what we call 49ers.
And after that, there are two senior organizations now.
the World Business Council, and the Chief Executives Organization, which George Mitchell and I belong to also.
And CEO, the latter one, Chief Executives Organization, you have to be voted into on a basis of your popularity, prominence, or your activities.
If you were active and CEO, a lot of people knew you and voted for you to come in.
George had a very prominent position.
He was chairman a couple years back.
And I've been on the board and all that kind of stuff.
And more than that, I've run conventions.
And frankly, whenever George got a difficult job to do and he didn't have time for it, he gave it to me.
Because he was the director and I was not, he was named to do a convention in Phoenix.
That must have been about 10 years ago now.
And he made me his vice chairman or something like that.
And I pulled the whole thing together.
And it was quite an extraordinary event.
We had a thing called Encounters, Strange Encounters with the Fourth Estate.
And we had Dan Rather and Rook Kaiser and Ted Koppel and Paul Conrad, the cartoonist.
The fellow who used to do sports.
He had a loud voice.
What was his name?
He's retired now.
Boxing and all that stuff.
I forget his name.
I know the voice.
You know the voice, yeah.
But we had an all-star aggregation of people talking about the relationship between business and the Fourth Estate.
It was fascinating.
George was the chairman of it, really.
But I did it.
He did it.
I got it.
He's pretty good at delegating things.
Yeah.
And George and I have been involved in things like that.
Wherever he gets involved in something, or I get involved in something, and I bring him into the thing, because of our friendship.
So we were on a mission once, on a journey.
YPO has had conventions, one domestic and one local.
And it's called the University for Presidents.
where you go to a site, either internationally or locally, you get a syllabus and a curriculum book, and you look through it and you select courses.
You and your wife can take the courses.
And it's gotten to a point now where it's an all-star faculty, because the best people from the universities and the best people in politics and literature want to speak to us.
You're such an influential group.
And we have a turn-down request from people.
But we've had Presidents of the United States, the top senators, the top scientists, you name them.
And I've become good friends with a number of people who've come that way.
And George and I were going to Greece.
He was actually going to the conference in Athens, and I was.
And George, as you may or may not know, seldom travels with his wife because they're brood.
They have 10 children.
It's a risky business when you've got that kind of a big family.
My wife and I always traveled together, although we only have three children.
That's a small family compared to the Mitchell family.
But George and I sat next to each other.
And he's a friendly guy, and we kept talking.
And he asked me what I do, and I asked what he does, and he said he's in the energy business.
He's such an unassuming guy, in a way, and an old shoe type of personality.
He said he was in the energy business.
I figured he had a couple of gas stations.
I didn't know where he had.
And he said, someday we're going to go public with my company.
Again, I realized it was a small company.
And he said, you know, we probably need public relations.
I'll give you a call.
And I guess we didn't talk for about six months or a year.
And he called me one day.
And he said, can you come down and talk to our people?
And I talked to his people.
And they interviewed.
They interviewed maybe six firms at that time.
Because they weren't going to accept somebody that George just met on a plane.
And we got the accounts.
And, of course, I would come down here on a very frequent basis as I realized some of the things George was doing.
What was his charge?
What was his interest in public relations at that point when you made that first contact?
Was it energy, selling energy?
Well, when you go public, you have a disclosure obligation.
So that was the motive, really, that he used?
Well, probably in the back of his mind, he said to himself, I'm going public, and I want to be sure there's an appreciation of my stock.
But you think first of disclosure obligations.
You know, it's really a pain in the neck to go public.
You've got responsibility.
You've got to turn on any report, quarterly reports.
You've got to interface with the security analysts.
You've got to be prone to certain kind of publicity, which George wasn't previously.
He was a very private person.
And you need some expert guidance in that mine field.
So that's number one.
I don't think George ever said to me, I wanted my stock to go up.
No, of course not.
No, I think most people don't do that.
But there's no question if you add good communications to a good profit picture, your stock's going to go up.
The public will appreciate it.
How did you evaluate or analyze, what was your impression of Mitchell Energy at that time, and of George Mitchell as a public corporation, let's say?
Well, I saw that he had great leadership potential.
I saw something that intrigued me that he was so brilliant and far-reaching and so visionary.
I hadn't run into anybody like that in a long time.
Out of my whole clientele, I probably dealt with maybe 500 chief executives through the years.
He was way ahead of them because there's only a couple of people I can think of in the United States
that function in the same league as George Mitchell.
Another dear friend of mine, Bob Galvin, who owns Motorola Company.
He's now become chairman of the executive committee.
He was chairman and chief executive for many years.
Motorola went from $200 million to about $6 billion today.
It takes that kind of vision and drive and ability to pull people around you, ability to take chances with people, a whole variety of things.
I could see that George's mind worked so rapidly.
The reason George talks fast is because he's trying to keep up with his mind.
It's moving very, very rapidly.
Yeah, we interviewed him.
It was very difficult to transcribe that interview.
I know, I know.
He moves so fast.
In a way, I guess he saw a kinship in me that I shared his dream.
Whatever it is, I got on the merry-go-round.
and went with him.
What I lent to that was, along the line, there were opportunities for dramatic execution of his ideas.
He sees me as a visionary, too, in terms of public relations, communications.
He kids that I'm his guru, I'm his public relations guru.
Well, it really isn't that.
He's got a
staff and all that.
But we talk and communicate, and I throw ideas at him, and sometimes he goes with them, sometimes he can't go with them, even if he wants to.
And I am unprecedented about bringing big ideas to him.
So about eight, I kicked myself, I couldn't sell it, but about, what was it, eight, ten years ago, I went to a man named Noguchi, a famous sculptor.
The Garden in Israel.
And somewhere along the line, I saw in one of his books that he did a children's playground out of sculpture.
I said, my God, what a thing that would be for the Woodlands.
And have Noguchi do a children's playground.
I think people come from all over the world to see it here.
Well, I think they would.
Yeah.
And I had a deal worked out with him.
And Noguchi asked me.
It would take about a quarter of a million dollars to do it.
I went to George with him.
He was very interested, in fact, to the extent where he started collecting books on Noguchi and all that.
But there was a decline right at that point in the energy market.
And he couldn't do it.
Cynthia Mitchell said to me recently, why didn't you tell me about it?
You know?
It may not be too late.
Well, he's dead.
And maybe the concept is still.
Well, I'm not giving an illustration of my brilliance.
I'm saying I was unhesitant about coming to George
with a big idea, because I know that he would listen, and he wouldn't deprecate you for thinking along those lines.
But my work was really not essentially big ideas.
My work was, first of all, to set the groundwork for a professional public relations firm, a program to communicate what Mitchell Energy was, essentially to the financial public.
How did you do that?

Well, what I'd like to know in a way, because neither of us are really all that familiar with what a professional public relations person does, if you could sort of outline in general terms what you would do given that situation and then reflect how that worked in the Woodlands, for example, and with Mitchell Energy and Development.
Whenever you're ready.
When you think of what we call financial public relations, there are various.
arenas that public relations people work in.
One is marketing public relations, where you try to sell a product and use certain techniques along those lines.
And I would say, in the case of the Woodlands, marketing public relations mostly comes to bear.
Do you want a Coke or something?
where you try to get publicity so people will come out here and see the project and hopefully buy.
You precondition the audience with exposure.
In the case of financial public relations, it's a different approach, yet some of the same techniques apply.
You have to think of financial public relations as a distribution system, and out there,
are security analysts who are really sales promotion then.
Security analyst has stock that he sells.
And then the consumer is a customer.
And so you have a whole distribution system.
You have to get information to those people.
And it's written, or it's personal identification, face to face.
It's annual reports, which they all depend upon and read.
And it's the interim reports.
So our function was to lay out that kind of a program first, and then to start doing the things that had to be done, mechanical or otherwise.
So it meant help with the preparation of the annual report, which is the most important document that goes out every year.
In addition to that, those interim statements have to go out.
You do publicity in newspapers, and you have an earnings report.
You report the earnings to the Dow Jones.
It gets on the broad tape, and it goes out to the newspapers.
And then you back that up with personal visits, presentations before security analysts, the analyst societies in the major cities, New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange.
And that meant we had to get George, however reluctant he felt about it, we had to get him on the road to go out and talk to some of those people.
We knew his personality would come to bear.
And there's nothing that's unprofessional or improper.
It's all part of the distribution.
setup that we have that's so efficient in the United States for bringing financial information to the people who should know.
And of course the stockholders get the same reports and they also read the newspapers.
It was important that we talked to the financial publications like Finance and Forbes and other publications like that.
So before long we had a man on our staff who traveled the country to the secondary markets
And there are certain markets who are never visited by a CEO.
Let's say in Lexington, Kentucky, or Jacksonville, Florida, where there are pockets of investors.
So what you do is you take a look at the transfer sheets, and you see where your investors are.
And you say, well, we've got 20 investors in Jacksonville.
It means they have friends.
Maybe we ought to go down there and make a report on what Mitchell is doing now.
And there are some communities where we know that there are
very important investors, and they don't own any shares in Mitchell.
And we may select that as the market that we should make a presentation.
And what you do sometimes is you approach the security firm that's making the market for you, your principal, underwriter, and say, well, you set up a meeting for us.
Or you go to your bank and say, well, you have your affiliate bank in Boston set up a meeting.
Or you go directly to the analyst society and say, we can bring George Mitchell down.
and would be happy to make a presentation.
And we help with the preparation of the presentation, so that when he goes there, he gives the right kind of speech.
And we don't write George's speech.
We may help with it.
Sure.
I don't want to give the impression that this is a talking head.
Yeah, that it's canned.
Yes, canned, or that he doesn't have his own thoughts about it.
George is very, very careful, very critical about things people want him to say.
Because he has his own intellectual acuity that he applies to everything that you ask him to do.
So that was that program.
Then the other program that was parallel was reporting on the energy business itself.
New developments.
You know, what you do is you write news stories or you do brochures or you start to analyze.
Let me put it this way.
In every public relations campaign, the first thing you do is to do some research to find out what the
public perception is of the company.
Then you do some internal interviews to find out the internal perception.
You work out some kind of adjustment between the two.
If there's an incorrect alignment between the two perceptions, you make an adjustment there.
Then you find out what the company feels it stands for, how it wants to be known, what its publics are.
make a very careful analysis of the people we have to reach.
Then we decide what the most effective means of communicating with those publics are.
Do you have difficulty, for example, often maybe, finding out what a company really wants to present itself as and helping to shape that?
Well, we use a variety of devices.
One is we may do focus groups, which we do frequently, to find out what they really mean.
Not what they're saying, but what they really mean.
We've used psychologists.
We've used a whole variety of devices.
Or sometimes it gets down to a one-on-one confrontation between me and the CEO.
Many times a CEO will hire us, and he's not quite sure where he's done it, but he thinks he needs it.
And then he resists it right away.
I assume that might have been the role of George Mitchell.
Was it, by chance?
Well, some of the things were at play.
He knew he needed you, but did he know what he wanted you to do?
Well, George has profound perceptions about a lot of things.
He knew he needed contact with the financial community, probably his brokerage firm, his underwriter told him.
And he had certain ideas about what he wasn't willing to do.
Even to this day, George doesn't like to go on the road.
That's the last thing in the world that he wants to do is go out and be a salesman.
for his company, but he will do it if it's urgent or important.
Like the New York Stock Exchange, the society there, or Chicago Key Markets, he will do maybe once a year.
But there was a time we had a man full-time doing that.
And now there still is a man in the company who's not on my staff, on the company staff.
Over the years, Mitchell Energy built up a very capable public relations staff whose head
until recently was Joe Cutchin, who was a member of our staff.
And George's people want to hire him.
I'll tell you that as an aside.
That's been reflective of George's personality and sense of integrity.
At one point, they decided they needed a public relations man internally.
His staff was pushing for it.
And George agreed to it.
Because there's so much going on.
Our agency couldn't handle it from the outside.
And I agreed with the concept.
They interviewed about 20 or 30 people.
Finally, one day George called me.
He said, you know, they've interviewed all kinds of people.
He's the only one they like is the guy on your staff, like Joe.
And I said, well, George, what do you want to do?
And he said, well, I told him they can't hire him unless you agree.
I think that was the benefit of our personal relationship.
He was protecting me.
And I said, George, what are you going to do for him?
Are you going to enhance his future?
Is he going to make more money?
Does he have stock options?
He says, yes.
I said, well, what can I say?
I said, are you going to keep the agency?
He said, of course.
And I said, well, why don't you just give me, maybe guarantee our contract at the end of the year or something.
He said, oh, no, that won't be enough.
He said, at the end of the year, they're going to come to me and say, well, we got this guy, we got Joe, we don't need the agency.
So I said, well, what do you want to do, George?
He said, I'm going to give you a long-term contract.
I think he gave me a three-year contract at that time, which lasted for 20 years, you know, until I retired, you know.
But Joe came in here from our staff, and then we appointed another executive who they liked very well, and we worked on the accounts.
And then somewhere along the line, I think when I merged my company and all that, or maybe slightly before that, there was no longer need for the company and the competent staff here.
So the firm didn't continue except on a sporadic basis.
And then when I retired, George came to me and said, do you think you could come down here and help us review what we do and all that stuff on a regular basis?
Yeah, I said, I don't have any conflict at that point because you haven't been a client for a number of years.
So, you know, my contract stipulates I guess I can't take an account until after two years or something, something crazy.
And I'm still on the payroll of my old agency for another two more years.
So I've come down there, and first he gave me the assignment of meeting with energy and with real estate, and then little by little I've gotten into HARC.
You know HARC?
Yeah, sure.
And yesterday I ran a seminar for the executives at Harc on public relations.
Did you?
Yeah, which is fascinating.
But going back, switching back, when George began to talk to me about the woodlands, to me it was a fascinating concept.
And when did that occur?
Do you remember when this new community woodlands idea really emerged?
All during the time I knew him, he talked about it.
He said that this came in part out of his New Presidents Association contacts.
I think Woodlands is what?
You probably know better than I.
It's probably in this book.
I can give you an idea.
He started turning this over somewhere in the 60s.
Of course, the Woodlands, I guess, as an entity, began about 1969, 1974.
But somewhere before that, he's .
Oh, before that, he was talking about it, sure.
If you tell me, if I can remember when they went public, which I can't at the moment.
We can find that out.
That's all right.
That was about the time I'll find it.

But as we spent time together and began to talk about the concept, and what amazed me, absolutely amazed me, was how he was approaching it from a standpoint of safeguarding the environment and bringing the best people that he could find.
you know, that deal with the preservation of the environment, the way out of the woodlands, the safety, safe streets.
He was creating a perfect home environment.
If I were fresh at that point in my life, I'd have moved into the woodlands.
My God, plenty offered there.
Perfect schooling for the kids, you know, and for preservation of flora and fauna, recreation, unlimited recreational activities.
I'm a golfer.
My God, they have three golf courses that are available, you know.
And you can buy a house down here for half the price of what I have to pay elsewhere.
Beautiful homes.
I know what I get for 3,000 feet in the Palm Springs area.
If you're spending anywhere from $700,000 to a million, 3,000 feet, or you might spend $350,000 at the most here.
At least I think so.
Yeah, but at any rate,
I was just so excited about what he was doing, so that's where he turned down the juices, and I tried to give as many ideas as I could and as much leadership.
I would say George got something out of me that I couldn't give to a lot of our clients.
At one point we had 150 clients, and I would only select a handful of clients I would personally work with.
In all cases, on the Mitchell account, I was on the top of the heap, because I was interfacing with George and with the executives here.
At times it was rough going because people were concerned about my close personal relationship with George if they had to work with me.
Because I had George's ear more than some people could get, and his confidence, and sometimes they were reluctant to talk to me about things that they wouldn't want George to hear.
So that's always the case.
You mean within the company?
Within a company, when you're very close to the top.
I very seldom had familial relationships with clients.
We didn't try to achieve that at all.
Just a small handful of people.
And it had to develop automatically.
The wives had to like each other first.
If they don't, then you're dead.
You're going to be killed.
And then you have to want to do things with one another, with the CEO, out of the business.
You want to spend time.
George and I have traveled the world together, our families.
I'm not only George's PR guru, I'm his restaurant grazer.
I'm his grazer.
When we go on a trip, first of all, George doesn't like to travel, and since we have a comfortable relationship, if he finds out that we're thinking of doing it too, it's mostly in connection
meetings of the senior YPO organization CEO.
We know a convention is going on and my wife will say, maybe we ought to take a post-convention trip.
They frequently offer trips.
After the five-day convention, you might go off somewhere with the group.
